en.value: I have a headache.
Talking about being unwell and describing how you feel - Modals of obligation: "should", "must" and "have to"
Are you feeling ok?
Here's a tip!
I have a headache.
I have a sore throat.
Do you feel sick?

When we're in a different country, it's helpful to be able to tell someone that we're not feeling well, so it's important to be prepared with some common phrases. We're now going to learn some ways to talk about different health issues. We'll learn phrases like:
Memorise the word(s).
Are you sick?
There are many different ways to ask how someone's doing. Have a look at some of them below:
Are you ok?
Are you tired?
Are you feeling sick?
How are you feeling?
How might we ask a friend how they're feeling if they don't look well?
Are you feeling ok?
Are you seeing ok?
I'm feeling ok.
True or false?
Are you sick?
This is a way of asking someone how they're feeling.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
to have a sore...
I've had a sore throat since yesterday.
to have a temperature
He has a high temperature. We should take him to the doctor's.
If someone has a high temperature they may also say "I have a fever".
I can't come, my son has a fever.
Select the way in which we would say that our back hurts.
I have a sore back.
I have a slow back.
I have a back.
to have a fever / to have a temperature
These have different meanings.
These have the same meaning.
to have a headache
Do you have any painkillers? I have a headache.
to feel sick
Do you feel sick?
There are many ways that we can say that we are feeling unwell. Have a look at some them below:
I feel dizzy.
I feel tired.
I don't feel well.
Select the word that describes a pain in your head.
I can't come out today, I have a [h]headache[/h].
Select the words in the correct order.
[k]Do[/k][k]you[/k][k]feel[/k][k]sick[/k][k]?[/k]
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
to suffer
He's really suffering with this cold.
to pick up a bug
I think I've picked up a bug. I don't feel great.
to get over
It took you ages to get over that cold.
We might say this if we're not feeling well: I've...
picked up a bug.
picked up a pug.
got over a cold.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
I'm taking it easy tonight, I just [k]got[/k] [k]over[/k] a cold.
come
under
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Peter's roommate asks him how he is.
Peter are you [k]feeling[/k] ok? You look [k]tired[/k].
Hmm not really, I think I've [k]picked up a bug[/k].
Oh no, I'm sorry to hear that. What exactly is wrong?
I have a [k]headache[/k] and a [k]sore throat[/k]. This morning I felt very [k]dizzy[/k]!
Do you have a [k]temperature[/k]?
No, I don't think so, but I haven't [k]suffered[/k] like this in a long time!
Well, I hope you [k]get over it[/k] quickly. But don't worry about the housework today, I can do it.
Thank you Margaret, I appreciate it!
Margaret
Peter
Fill in the gap using the audio.
I hope I don't have a [k]temperature[/k].
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Please be quiet, I have a h[k]e[/k][k]a[/k]da[k]c[/k][k]h[/k][k]e[/k]!
Mmmm, not really. I think I [k]picked up a bug[/k].
Type in the box to ask someone how they are feeling.
[k]Are you ok?|Are you feeling ok?|Are you tired?|Are you sick?|Are you feeling sick?|How are you feeling?[/k]
Listen and select all of Peter's symptoms.
sore throat, feeling dizzy, headache
earache, feeling tired, fever
sore throat, sore back, headache
I just [k]got over[/k] a bad cold.
No, I don't think so, but I haven't [k]suffered[/k] like this in a long time!
[k]I[/k] [k]picked[/k] [k]up[/k] [k]a[/k] [k]bug.[/k]
Fill in the gap using the hint.
Complete to ask if someone is feeling ill.
Are you feeling [k]sick[/k]?
Talk about a time you were ill. How did you feel? What were your symptoms?
the flu / a cold / sick / awful / terrible / a headache / a sore throat / have a high temperature
Grammar: Expressing obligation and necessity

When we follow someone's advice, a general rule or a law, there is often some sense of obligation implied. Words like "should", "have to" and "must" help us express various levels of obligation connected to our actions. Let's take a look!
You should eat more vitamins.
I must tell my boss that I picked up a bug.
You have to work at 10am.
You should eat more vitamins.
The sentence gives advice.
You have to work on Sunday this week.
This sentence is indicating obligation.

"Should", "have to" and "must" belong to a group of words called modal verbs. These go right in front of the main verb in a sentence and they give more meaning to the verb. The modal verb "have to" changes according to the person doing the action, the main verb remains in its original form. person + modal verb + main verb (original from) + rest of sentence.
She has to go to a conference.
I should call my supervisor.
We must get to the party on time.
What do modal verbs do?
give meaning to the main verb
replace the main verb
put emphasis on the main verb

We use "should" to give advice to someone. It is much stronger than a simple suggestion or recommendation, as you can see below. We use it to express that we think there is basically no better option.
Weaker suggestion: You could ask your manager for some time off.
Stronger suggestion: You should ask your manager for some time off.
should
You should get some rest.
When do we use "should"?
to give advice
to express necessity
to give someone a task

We use "must" to say that it is necessary or very important that something happens. We can also use it to recommend something ("You must try this new restaurant!" X) or to make assumptions ("You must be so tired!" X).
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
must
I must schedule an appointment for my check-up.
When do we use "must"?
We usually use "to have to" when the obligation comes from someone else, e.g. when we follow an order or a rule, but you'll also hear it with a meaning similar to "must".
She has to give a presentation tomorrow.
She has to buy a gift for Sarah.
to have to
She has to hand in her sick note within three days.
When do we use "to have to"?
when we follow an order
when talking about a plan
Select the modal verbs.
She [h]has[/h] [h]to[/h] call in sick.
I [h]should[/h] probably go to the dentist.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
I [k]should[/k] go to the dentist soon.
want to
[k]We[/k] [k]have[/k] [k]to[/k] [k]be[/k] [k]on time[/k][k].[/k]
I [k]must[/k] get a new chair, this one is giving me back pain.
may
Select the two words that show that this is advice.
You [h]suggested[/h] I work from home on Monday.
She [h]should[/h] rest more before coming back to work.
Instead of saying "should" we can give a slightly weaker suggestion by saying "I suggest (that)". It's a polite way of suggesting what you think someone should do.
I suggest that you visit a doctor.
My manager suggested that I work from home today.
I [k]suggest[/k] you talk to your manager about it.
should
He [k]h[/k][k]a[/k][k]s[/k] [k]t[/k][k]o[/k] drive everyone home.
Complete the sentence to say that the action is necessary or very important.
You [k]must[/k] RSVP first.
should
"To need to" has a similar meaning to "have to" or "must". We can use it to explain a rule, give advice or express our plans, as you can see below.
You need to hand in your sick note within three days.
He needs to pick up some groceries after work.
I need to find a replacement for my shift on Sunday.
I need to pick up some groceries after work.
This has a similar meaning to "must".
[k]I[/k] [k]need[/k] [k]to[/k] [k]cancel[/k] [k]my[/k] [k]doctor's appointment[/k][k].[/k]

Remember that the context and meaning of the words we've just learned can be quite similar. There's no rigid rule that tells us when to use "have to" and when to use "must", for example, so no need to be confused when people use some of them interchangeably.
Select the words that show that this was necessary / obligatory.
He [h]had[/h] [h]to[/h] give the presentation with a cold.
I [h]needed[/h] [h]to[/h] bring flowers to the birthday party.
Complete the sentence to say that the action was an order.
I [k]had to[/k] work last weekend.
should
Listen to the audio. What does it imply?
advice
an order
a necessity
You've been feeling sick all day, you [k]should[/k] really see a doctor.
I [k]suggest[/k] you talk to your manager about it.
a wish
I don't think it's fair that Sarah has to work weekends all the time. She [k]needs to[/k] relax too.
Maria [k]has to[/k] finish her presentation tonight.
We [k]must|have to|need to[/k] find someone to cover for Lionel, he's off sick.
